results.title: The Bill. Gentleman Jim
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘Gentleman Jim’ contains three episodes of ‘The Bill’ featuring Jim Carver (Mark Wingett). Wingett wrote the first of these three episodes. ‘Saved’ (1995, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Jeremy Silberston): back in his drinking days Jim Carver is loosing his faith in the police force and in particular, his usefulness. To combat his so called “desk fatigue”, he is called to help in a raid on a crack house. Jim helps a prostitute - restoring his sense of worth. ‘True to life player’ (1997, produced by Chris Clough, directed by Simon Meyers): focuses on a once local boy’s rise to fame as a footballer who is accused of rape by an underage girl. Is she lying, or is he? As the story unfolds the audience is in doubt while Jim Carver plays his role as investigating officer. ‘Gentleman Jim’ (1997, produced by Pat Sandys, directed by Mike Vardy): Jim is teamed up with an overly enthusiastic uniformed officer on secondment in C.I.D. Her drive and initiative conflicts with the slightly stale and crabby Jim. Experience wins over enthusiasm and Jim reveals himself as the decent man and policeman that he is.

results.title: The Bill. A bunch of fives
results.brief_description: ‘The Bill’ is a UK police drama that explores both criminals and police. ‘A Bunch of fives’ (1997, produced by Michael Simpson, directed by Chris Lovett): one of the Sunhill officers is found beaten unconscious in an alley at the back of a Chinese restaurant. This causes a zero tolerance stance from the rest of the officers while they try to find the culprit. Does a policeman need to be beaten before the police do any work at Sunhill? ‘Death of a nobody’ (1996, produced by Chris Clough, directed by Simon Meyers): a man is found murdered. A mystery unfolds when he’s identified as a choir singing, onion growing taxi driver. Have they killed the wrong man? A polaroid, an answering machine and a suspicious private investigator are the only clues in this mysterious one hour episode.

results.title: The Bike
results.brief_description: An open-ended film in which two boys use another boy’s bike without permission and break it. Raises quiestions about property and responsibility for one’s actions. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Biggest epidemic of our times. Pt. 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
The second of two programs in which doctors, police and accident investigation teams powerfully demonstrate the need for greater care on the roads. This episode focuses on the problems of motorcyclists and the safety regulations of helmets.

results.title: The Biggest epidemic of our times. Pt. 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
The first of two programs in which doctors, police and accident investigation teams powerfully demonstrate the need for greater care on the roads. This episode presents the statistics on British road accidents and discusses the legislation on seat belts.

results.title: The Biggest bug
results.creator_credit: Austral Pacific Productions and British Petroleum
results.brief_description: A film made for the Keep Australia Beautiful Council. A satirical attack on the practice of dumping rubbish and a plea to Australians to preserve the beauty of their country. A family picnics in a suburban garden and leaves it as littered as many people do when picnicking in the country. The film ends with the well-known slogan “Don’t rubbish Australia”! Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: The Bigamist
results.creator_credit: Collier Young, Filmmakers, Republic Pictures Corporation and Ida Lupino
results.brief_description: A childless couple, Harry (Edmund O’Brien) and Eve Graham (Joan Fontaine) apply to adopt a child in their home city of San Francisco. The meticulous adoption agent, Mr Jordan (Edmund Gwenn) suspects something is awry and investigates every corner of Harry’s life before approving the adoption. He soon discovers that Harry has another life and another wife (Ida Lupino) in Los Angeles. Before Jordan reports Harry to the police he listens to his story. Ida Lupino was one of the few women directors working regularly in Hollywood during the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s. She also produced and wrote for both film and television during this period. Her acting career spanned fifty years from the 1930s to the 1980s.

results.title: The Big wet
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Discovery Productions and Jeremy Hogarth
results.brief_description: The monsoon season is the most dramatic of all seasons in Australia, but each year it is different. “The Big wet” is the chronicle of a particularly wet monsoon in the tropical north. It starts with the last days of the dry in September and concludes with the first fires in April. The film looks at the effect it has on all living things in the Top End, particularly the salt-water crocodile, the wallabies and the magpie goose. Featured throughout the program is the majestic scenery of Kakadu and Arnhem Land. Narrated by John Waters.

results.title: The Big trail (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Raoul Walsh
results.brief_description: The Big Trail covers the journey of hundreds of settlers in covered wagons from the Mississippi River to their destiny out west. John Wayne as Breck Coleman leads them through the rugged terrain and falls in love on the way.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Raoul Walsh

results.title: The Big stride
results.creator_credit: Peter Bale, BBC-TV and John Dobson
results.brief_description: Tells of the construction of Britain’s second-longest suspension bridge, across the River Severn, from its earliest beginnings to its opening by Queen Elizabeth in 1966. In terms of scientific advance, economy and beauty it is superlative, and its construction points the way to the bridge across the Humber which will be the biggest in the world.
